title: Add the Aviator capability for your tenant
content:
With the ITOM Aviator license, you can add the Aviator capability for your tenant as the suite admin. Be aware that once you enable this capability, you won't be able to disable it afterward.

Get required fields for deployment

Before the deployment, contact the support team to get the values for the following fields that are required in the Pre-check step during the deployment: Token URL, Client ID, Client secret, Base URL, and API key.

(Optional) Configure proxy in Suite Administration

If your suite needs to use a proxy server to connect to the internet, you need to configure a proxy server before deploying Aviator.

For details, see the Proxy Settings tab section in Configurations.

Deploy Aviator

You can deploy and enable the Aviator capability for a tenant that meets the following requirements:

  • The backend type of the tenant is SMAX.
  • The status of the tenant is Active.

To do this, follow these steps:

  1. Log in to Suite Administration (https://<EXTERNAL_ACCESS_HOST>/bo) as the suite admin.
  2. From the main menu, click Tenants, and then click the tenant in the ID column to display the selected tenant.
  3. Click the Capability settings tab.
  4. On the page that appears, click Deploy new capability.
    This opens a dialog box with two steps: Pre-check and Config and deploy.
  5. In the Pre-check step, set the following fields with information obtained from the support team.
     
    FieldDescription
    CapabilityThe new capability you want to deploy. Select ITOM Aviator.
    Token URL

    The URL of the token used to authenticate the client ID. 

    Example: https://test-auth.itsma.com/oauth2/token

    Client IDThe ID used to identify the customer. Each tenant has a unique ID. 
    Client secretThe secret key of the client.
    Base URL

    The base URL of the Aviator API. 

    Example: https://test-api.itsma.com

    API keyThe key used to call the Aviator API. 
  6. Click NEXT. This will take you to the Config and deploy step.
  7. Select the tip that alerts you to the irreversible nature of enabling this capability, and then click DEPLOY.
    A message will appear indicating that the deployment has started.
  8. Click CLOSE.
    The specified fields will appear in the ITOM Aviator section. The auto-generated field Remote ID is the unique ID of the remote Aviator service. You'll need this field if you experience some issues when using the Aviator service.
  9. Click Refresh and view the Deploy status field to check whether the deployment is successful.
    • In progress: indicates that the deployment is in progress.
    • Done: indicates that the deployment is successful.
    • Failed: indicates that the deployment has failed.
      You can either click the Operation history field or the Operation history tab in the left panel to check the logs for more details. Resolve the issues, and then click REDEPLOY to try again.
  10. (Optional) Click TEST CONNECTION to verify that your settings are correct. Make changes based on the test results.
  11. Toggle on Enable capability and confirm that you want to enable this capability.
  12. Click SAVE.

After adding the Aviator capability, the system will automatically create an AviatorUser role. You can use this role to control user access to the Aviator capability. 

Reindex offerings and articles

Perform this task if you want Aviator to use your existing offering and article data on your tenant.

To perform a full reindex for existing offerings and articles, run this command: 

./reindex.sh <Service_Management_FQDN> -t <tenantid_1,tenantid_2> -P <pwd of integration user:bo-integration@dummy.com> -T Offering,Article

For more information, see Perform a full reindex for Aviator.

Create an integration user

Perform this task if you want to use the Aviator business rule Call Aviator with record data.

To create an integration user, follow the instructions in How to create a user.

After creating the integration user, securely share the username and password of the integration user with the tenant admin for later use.

Apply update for using Aviator in cross-domain integration

If Aviator capability is enabled, update the Suite configuration to allow seamless cross-domain integration You can skip this configuration update if you already applied it during Service Management  installation or upgrade.

The placeholder used in the commands in this section are as follows:

  • <release name>: The release name.
  • <suite namespace>:  Unique namespace of the ESM deployment.
  • <ESM helm chart path>: Path to the helm charts tar file. This file is located in the charts folder.

Complete the following steps to update the configuration.

  1. Run the following command. If it returns SMAX_AUTH_TOKEN_COOKIE_SAMESITE: None, the cross‑domain setup is complete and you can skip the remaining steps. 
    kubectl get cm itom-bo-configmap -n <suite namespace> -o yaml | grep "SMAX_AUTH_TOKEN_COOKIE_SAMESITE: None"
  2. Get the deployment YAML values into a file named my-values.yaml. 
    helm get values <release name> -n <suite namespace> > my-values.yaml
  3. Run the following command to apply configuration update. 
    helm upgrade <release name> <ESM helm chart path> -n <suite namespace> -f my-values.yaml -f <ESM helm chart path>/samples/enableSMAXAuthTokenSameSiteNone-values.yaml
  4. Restart the pods. 
    kubectl rollout restart deployment itom-bo-login-deployment -n <suite namespace>

Aviator limitations in cross-domain integration scenarios

The following limitations apply to Aviator users in cross-domain integration scenarios. An example of cross-domain integration scenario is when your Suite deployment is integrated with other products such as AI Operations Management (AIOM) or Universal Discovery and CMDB (UD/UCMDB) for information exchange.

  • If you open Aviator in a private browsing mode, such as Incognito in Chrome, it may not return any responses to your requests.

  • While using Aviator, if the session times out, you may be asked to log in again.
